prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO J=1-0 Observations of GMCs in NGC 1326's Nuclear Ring
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will use ALMA to determine fundamental properties of GMCs within the robustly star forming nuclear ring of NGC 1326. These include sizes, velocity widths, CO luminosities, etc.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have conservatively chosen a wide total spectral bandwidth (1224 km/s) for our line observations to ensure ample channels for continuum subtraction. The channel separation (0.64 km/s) was chosen to give us extra flexibility in binning our data if necessary to bring out faint emission.

In order to just resolve a typical Galactic disk GMC the smallest, lowest mass GMC of interest to our study - we require an angular resolution of 0.3arcsec FWHM (19 pc). With this angular resolution we will easily resolve the larger and more massive GMCs in the ring. This will also allow us to make detailed comparisons between the GMCs and HII complexes/star clusters visible in our ancillary data. We will experiment with angular resolution and velocity binning in the map making phase to better determine the GMC population properties. NGC 1326s inner ring has a diameter of 12.5arcsec which is comparable to the largest well imaged angular scale, and we expect to recover essentially all of the rings line emission.

At NGC 1326s distance (16 Mpc) a typical Galactic disk GMC (R~20 pc, dV~2.5 km/s, M~1.5x10^5 solar masses) would be expected to produce a 12CO(J=1-0) line flux density of 17 mJy/beam for a 0.3arcsec (19 pc) synthesized beam and a velocity resolution of 1.25 km/s. A 5-sigma detection will require an rms of 3.4 mJy. We will integrate long enough to reach an rms of 3.0 mJy (in a single pointing centered on the ring) with a velocity resolution of 1.25 km/s. According to the ALMA Cycle-3 OT this will require 1.84-hours, including calibration and overheads. The larger and more massive GMCs we expect to find in the ring (R~20 pc and M>10^6 solar masses) will be resolved with higher S/N.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO J=1-0 Observations of GMCs in NGC 2997's Nuclear Ring
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will use ALMA to determine fundamental properties of GMCs within the robustly star forming nuclear ring of NGC 2997. These include sizes, velocity widths, CO luminosities, etc.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have conservatively chosen a wide total spectral bandwidth (1224 km/s) for our line observations to ensure ample channels for continuum subtraction. The channel separation (0.64 km/s) was chosen to give us extra flexibility in binning our data if necessary to bring out faint emission.

In order to just resolve a typical Galactic disk GMC the smallest, lowest mass GMC of interest to our study - we require an angular resolution of 0.3arcsec FWHM (19 pc). With this angular resolution we will easily resolve the larger and more massive GMCs in the ring. This will also allow us to make detailed comparisons between the GMCs and HII complexes/star clusters visible in our ancillary data. We will experiment with angular resolution and velocity binning in the map making phase to better determine the GMC population properties. NGC 2997 inner ring has a diameter of 11arcsec which is comparable to the largest well imaged angular scale, and we expect to recover essentially all of the rings line emission.

At NGC 2997s distance (13 Mpc) a typical Galactic disk GMC (R~20 pc, dV~2.5 km/s, M~1.5x10^5 solar masses) would be expected to produce a 12CO(J=1-0) line flux density of 26 mJy/beam for a 0.3arcsec (19 pc) synthesized beam and a velocity resolution of 1.25 km/s. A 5-sigma detection will require an rms of 5.1 mJy. We will integrate long enough to reach an rms of 5.0 mJy (in a single pointing centered on the ring) with a velocity resolution of 1.25 km/s. According to the ALMA Cycle-3 OT this will require 0.98-hours, including calibration and overheads. The larger and more massive GMCs we expect to find in the ring (R~20 pc and M>10^6 solar masses) will be readily with higher S/N.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO J=1-0 Observations of GMCs in NGC 5248's Nuclear Ring
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will use ALMA to determine fundamental properties of GMCs within the robustly star forming nuclear ring of NGC 5248. These include sizes, velocity widths, CO luminosities, etc.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have conservatively chosen a wide total spectral bandwidth (1224 km/s) for our line observations to ensure ample channels for continuum subtraction. The channel separation (0.64 km/s) was chosen to give us extra flexibility in binning our data if necessary to bring out faint emission.

In order to just resolve a typical Galactic disk GMC the smallest, lowest mass GMC of interest to our study - we require an angular resolution of 0.3arcsec FWHM (19 pc). With this angular resolution we will easily resolve the larger and more massive GMCs in the ring. This will also allow us to make detailed comparisons between the GMCs and HII complexes/star clusters visible in our ancillary data. We will experiment with angular resolution and velocity binning in the map making phase to better determine the GMC population properties. NGC 5248s inner ring has a diameter of 15arcsec which is comparable to the largest well imaged angular scale, and we expect to recover essentially all of the rings line emission.

At NGC 5248s distance (17 Mpc) a typical Galactic disk GMC (R~20 pc, dV~2.5 km/s, M~1.5x10^5 solar masses) would be expected to produce a 12CO(J=1-0) line flux density of 15.5 mJy/beam for a 0.3arcsec (19 pc) synthesized beam and a velocity resolution of 1.25 km/s. A 5-sigma detection will require an rms of 3.1 mJy. We will integrate long enough to reach an rms of 3.0 mJy (in a single pointing centered on the ring) with a velocity resolution of 1.25 km/s. According to the ALMA Cycle-3 OT this will require 2.61 -hours, including calibration and overheads. The larger and more massive GMCs we expect to find in the ring (R~20 pc and M>10^6 solar masses) will be resolved with higher S/N.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCN/HCO+ J=1-0 Observations of GMCs in NGC 1326's Nuclear RIng
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will use ALMA to probe dense (n>10^4 cm-3) gas in GMC cores in the robustly star forming nuclear ring of NGC 1326 using the J = 1-0 transitions of HCN and HCO+.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have conservatively chosen a wide total spectral bandwidth (1224 km/s) for our line observations to ensure ample channels for continuum subtraction. The channel separation (0.64 km/s) was chosen to give us extra flexibility in binning our data if necessary to bring out faint emission.

In order to just resolve a typical Galactic disk GMC the smallest, lowest mass GMC of interest to our study - we require an angular resolution of 0.3arcsec FWHM (19 pc). With this angular resolution we will easily resolve the larger and more massive GMCs in the ring. This will also allow us to make detailed comparisons between the GMCs and HII complexes/star clusters visible in our ancillary data. We will experiment with angular resolution and velocity binning in the map making phase to better determine the GMC population properties. NGC 1326s inner ring has a diameter of 12.5arcsec which is comparable to the largest well imaged angular scale, and we expect to recover essentially all of the rings line emission.

Assuming that I(HCN)/I(CO)=0.1, as is found in other robustly star forming galaxies (e.g., Imanishi et al. 2007), the expected integrated HCN line flux from a typical Galactic GMC would be 6.6 mJy km/s. For a 0.4arcsec synthesized beam we would expect a typical line flux density of 3 mJy/beam. A 5-sigma detection requires reaching an rms of 0.6 mJy which can be reached in 1.82-hours for a velocity resolution of 15 km/s according to the ALMA Cycle-3 OT, including time for overheads and calibration. We expect I(HCO+)/I(HCN)~1, so the above considerations apply for the HCO+ observations. NGC 1326s nuclear ring diameter (12.5arcsec) is small and we expect to recover essentially all of its line emission.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCN/HCO+ J=1-0 Observations of GMCs in NGC 2997's Nuclear Ring
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will use ALMA to probe dense (n>10^4 cm-3) gas in GMC cores in the robustly star forming nuclear ring of NGC 2997 using the J = 1-0 transitions of HCN and HCO+.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have conservatively chosen a wide total spectral bandwidth (1224 km/s) for our line observations to ensure ample channels for continuum subtraction. The channel separation (0.64 km/s) was chosen to give us extra flexibility in binning our data if necessary to bring out faint emission.

In order to just resolve a typical Galactic disk GMC the smallest, lowest mass GMC of interest to our study - we require an angular resolution of 0.3arcsec FWHM (19 pc). With this angular resolution we will easily resolve the larger and more massive GMCs in the ring. This will also allow us to make detailed comparisons between the GMCs and HII complexes/star clusters visible in our ancillary data. We will experiment with angular resolution and velocity binning in the map making phase to better determine the GMC population properties. NGC 2997 inner ring has a diameter of 11arcsec which is comparable to the largest well imaged angular scale, and we expect to recover essentially all of the rings line emission.

Assuming that I(HCN)/I(CO)=0.1, as is found in other robustly star forming galaxies (e.g., Imanishi et al. 2007), the expected integrated HCN line flux from a typical Galactic GMC would be 10 mJy km/s. For a 0.4arcsec synthesized beam we would expect a typical line flux density of 4.3 mJy/beam. A 5-sigma detection requires reaching an rms of 0.86 mJy which can be reached in 1.45-hours for a velocity resolution of 10 km/s according to the ALMA Cycle-3 OT, including time for overheads and calibration. We expect I(HCO+)/I(HCN)~1, so the above considerations apply for the HCO+ observations. NGC 2997s nuclear ring diameter (11arcsec) is small and we expect to recover essentially all of its line emission.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCN/HCO+ J=1-0 Observations of GMCs in NGC 5248's Nuclear Ring
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will use ALMA to probe dense (n>10^4 cm-3) gas in GMC cores in the robustly star forming nuclear ring of NGC 5248 using the J = 1-0 transitions of HCN and HCO+.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have conservatively chosen a wide total spectral bandwidth (1224 km/s) for our line observations to ensure ample channels for continuum subtraction. The channel separation (0.64 km/s) was chosen to give us extra flexibility in binning our data if necessary to bring out faint emission

In order to just resolve a typical Galactic disk GMC the smallest, lowest mass GMC of interest to our study - we require an angular resolution of 0.3arcsec FWHM (19 pc). With this angular resolution we will easily resolve the larger and more massive GMCs in the ring. This will also allow us to make detailed comparisons between the GMCs and HII complexes/star clusters visible in our ancillary data. We will experiment with angular resolution and velocity binning in the map making phase to better determine the GMC population properties. NGC 5248s inner ring has a diameter of 15arcsec which is comparable to the largest well imaged angular scale, and we expect to recover essentially all of the rings line emission.

Assuming that I(HCN)/I(CO)=0.1, as is found in other robustly star forming galaxies (e.g., Imanishi et al. 2007), the expected integrated HCN line flux from a typical Galactic GMC would be 5.9 mJy km/s. For a 0.4arcsec synthesized beam we would expect a typical line flux density of 2.9 mJy/beam. A 5-sigma detection requires reaching an rms of 0.58 mJy which can be reached in 1.96-hours for a velocity resolution of 15 km/s according to the ALMA Cycle-3 OT, including time for overheads and calibration. We expect I(HCO+)/I(HCN)~1, so the above considerations apply for the HCO+ observations. NGC 5248s nuclear ring diameter (15arcsec) is small and we expect to recover essentially all of its line emission.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to use ALMA to determine the fundamental properties of the giant molecular cloud population (luminosity, size, velocity dispersion and mass) in a uniform sample of star forming nuclear rings (diameter ~ 12 ~ 1kpc) in barred galaxies. The objective is to detect emission from a GMCs of size 20 pc and mass 10^5 Msun using HCN(J=1-0) and HCO+(J=1-0) emission lines to trace the dense gas and 12CO (J=1-0) to trace the bulk gas in each ring. This study will provide valuable insights into the formation and evolution of GMCs, and what drives the rate and efficiency of star formation in an environment markedly different to spiral arms in a disk, and more akin to that found in starburst galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00720.S PI James Higdon. The ``Over-Cooked'' ISM in the Cartwheel Ring Galaxy (ApJ Letter submitted)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics, Georgia Southern University

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics, Georgia Southern University
